MS MCQs

    Introduction to application types in Business Central

    »

    1. What is the main difference between a connect app and an add-on app?  

      The main difference between a connect and an add-on app is that a connect app acts as an interface between Business Central and another service, while an add-on app acts as a link between two dependent apps.

      The main difference between a connect and an add-on app is that a connect app acts as a link between two dependent apps, while an add-on app extends Business Central functionality horizontally or vertically.

      The main difference between a connect and an add-on app is that an add-on app acts as an interface between Business Central and another service, while a connect app extends Business Central functionality horizontally or vertically.

      The main difference between a connect and an add-on app is that a connect app acts as an interface between Business Central and another service, while an add-on app extends Business Central functionality horizontally or vertically.


    2. What is a library app?

      A library app contains common code that other apps depend on.

      A library app depends on other apps that contain common code.

      A library app acts as an interface between Business Central and another service.

      A library app contains code that other apps are unable to extend.


    3. What is a code analyzer?

      A code analyzer is a connect app that builds on the compiler’s functionality to offer enhanced analysis of the syntax and semantics of your code at build time.

      A code analyzer is an add-on app that builds on the compiler’s functionality to offer enhanced analysis of the syntax and semantics of your code at build time.

      A code analyzer is an extension that builds on the compiler’s functionality to offer enhanced analysis of the syntax and semantics of your code at build time.

      A code analyzer is a library that builds on the compiler’s functionality to offer enhanced analysis of the syntax and semantics of your code at build time.
